docs.title: Fetching and Resetting Client Credentials
docs.description: Once you have registered as a consumer or have been approved as a provider, you may obtain your default client credentials.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: The IUDX Auth Consumer APIs allows a consumer to request and obtain tokens to access open and secure resources. Access information related to a resource can be understood via the Consumer Panel

docs.title: Data Access through APIs
docs.description: After discovering resources and obtaining appropriate access tokens, a consumer can use the Resource Access APIs to query a resource using temporal, spatial and attribute queries. It is to be noted that all the APIs are accessible only through a valid resource id and an appropriate Open or Secure access token.

docs.title: Data Access through Async APIs
docs.description: To use the Async Service, a consumer must request for consent from the provider, obtain a token from IUDX Auth server and then access the Async Resource Access API.

docs.title: Data Access through File Server
docs.description: After discovering resources and obtaining appropriate access tokens, a consumer can use the File Access APIs to query a resource using temporal, spatial and attribute queries. It is to be noted that all the APIs are accessible only through a valid resource id and an appropriate Open or Secure access token.

docs.title: Data Access through Subscription
docs.description: To register subscription, a user must request for consent from the provider, obtain a token from IUDX Auth server and then access the Subscription API.

docs.title: Discover Resources
docs.description: With the help of Catalogue APIs, a consumer can access information related to availability of a resource using spatial, attribute, text and relationship search.

docs.title: Obtaining Access Token
docs.description: To access a resource after discovering from the catalogue, a consumer should obtain Access Token using IUDX Authorisation Servers Create Token APIs.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: The IUDX Auth Auth-Delegate APIs allow assigned delegates to manage policies and delegations on behalf of the providers who have assigned them. Auth-Delegates may perform these operations using the Publisher Panel.

next.title: Managing Policies and Delegations for different Providers

docs.title: Managing Policies and Delegations for different Providers
docs.description: In the Publisher Panel, an Auth-Delegate may view and switch between the Providers who have granted them access. Once a Provider is chosen, the Delegate can view, create and delete both policies and delegations for said Provider.

previous.title: Managing Policies and Delegations for different Providers

docs.title: Deployment Overview
docs.description: IUDX platform can be deployed in Docker Swarm using the scripts and Swarm code present in this directory and sub-directories. Each component is deployed as a single instance in Swarm. The components can be scaled manually. IUDX platform exposes endpoints through two ports - one for HTTPS traffic which it passes to Nginx and Nginx routes to the appropriate service; another for Rabbitmq management and AMQPS streaming. The whole system is monitored using a monitoring stack module - Prometheus for metrics, promtail and Loki for logs, and Grafana for visualization and alerting. The overall architecture of Swarm deployment is summarized in the figure below.

docs.title: Centralised-Nginx
docs.description: + It acts as reverse proxy doing TLS termination, rate limiting for all (HTTP) public/outward facing IUDX endpoints

docs.title: Keycloak
docs.description: Keycloak is used as an Identity Manager and will be deployed using swarm stack YAML files.

docs.title: Latest-Ingestion-Pipeline
docs.description: Will be deploying using swarm stack yaml files.

docs.title: PostgreSQL
docs.description: - PostgreSQL is being used as a credentials and policy data store.

docs.title: RabbitMQ
docs.description: - RabbitMQ is utilized as a databroker in the IUDX system.

docs.title: Redis
docs.description: Redis is used as the latest-data store and will be deployed using Swarm stack YAML files.

docs.title: Resource-Server
docs.description: will be deployed using swarm stack YAML files.

docs.title: Zookeeper
docs.description: Before running any API servers or monitoring stack, Zookeeper has to be running.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.description: Basic knowledge on following DevOps Technologies

docs.title: IUDX Overview
docs.description: The IUDX platform consists of various IUDX-built services and open-source components. The overview IUDX platform with components is shown in the below figure.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: The IUDX Auth Provider APIs allow a provider to manage access to the secure resources they own via the Publisher Panel

docs.title: Manage Delegations
docs.description: Providers can delegate administrative tasks to pre-approved users having the delegate role. Delegates are assigned to a specific IUDX server which determines their capabilities.

docs.title: Manage Policies
docs.description: A provider can create, view and delete access policies set for consumers and delegates in the Consumers tab.

docs.title: Manage Catalogue Items
docs.description: Obtain Token to Create Catalogue

docs.title: Manage Data Ingestion
docs.description: Obtain Token to Ingest Data

metadata.title: Welcome
metadata.description: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

blogPosts.content:
[Docusaurus blogging features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/blog) are powered by the [blog plugin](https://docusaurus.io/docs/api/plugins/@docusaurus/plugin-content-blog).

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the `blog` directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to `authors.yml`.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

- `2019-05-30-welcome.md`
- `2019-05-30-welcome/index.md`

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

![Docusaurus Plushie](./docusaurus-plushie-banner.jpeg)

The blog supports tags as well!

**And if you don't want a blog**: just delete this directory, and use `blog: false` in your Docusaurus config.

metadata.title: MDX Blog Post
metadata.description: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.

blogPosts.content:
Blog posts support [Docusaurus Markdown features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/markdown-features), such as [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/).

:::tip

Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts.

```js
<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>
```

<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>

:::

metadata.title: Long Blog Post
metadata.description: This is the summary of a very long blog post,

blogPosts.content:
This is the summary of a very long blog post,

Use a `<!--` `truncate` `-->` comment to limit blog post size in the list view.

<!--truncate-->
